title: Enterobiasis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agent

The nematode (roundworm) _Enterobius vermicularis_ is widely known as the
human pinworm due to the female’s long, pointed tail. In some areas the common
names “seatworm” and “threadworm” are used (the latter of which is sometimes
also used to refer to [_Strongyloides
stercoralis_](/dpdx/strongyloidiasis/index.html))_._ Another putative pinworm
species, _Enterobius gregorii_ , has been described and reported from humans
in Europe, Africa, and Asia. However, further morphologic and molecular
evidence suggests _E. gregorii_ likely represents an immature form of _E.
vermicularis._ The rat pinworm, _Syphacia obvelata_ , has also very rarely
been reported infecting humans.

### Life Cycle

[![lifecycle](/dpdx/enterobiasis/modules/Enterobius_LifeCycl_19.jpg?_=58662)](/dpdx/enterobiasis/modules/Enterobius_LifeCycl_lg.jpg)

[View Larger](/dpdx/enterobiasis/modules/Enterobius_LifeCycl_lg.jpg)

Gravid adult female _Enterobius vermicularis_ deposit eggs on perianal folds
![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/1.jpg) . Infection occurs via
self-inoculation (transferring eggs to the mouth with hands that have
scratched the perianal area) or through exposure to eggs in the environment
(e.g. contaminated surfaces, clothes, bed linens, etc.)
![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/2.jpg) . Following ingestion of
infective eggs, the larvae hatch in the small intestine
![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/3.jpg) and the adults establish
themselves in the colon, usually in the cecum
![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/4.jpg) . The time interval from
ingestion of infective eggs to oviposition by the adult females is about one
month. At full maturity adult females measure 8 to 13 mm, and adult males 2 to
5 mm; the adult life span is about two months. Gravid females migrate
nocturnally outside the anus and oviposit while crawling on the skin of the
perianal area ![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/5.jpg) . The larvae
contained inside the eggs develop (the eggs become infective) in 4 to 6 hours
under optimal conditions ![image](/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/new/1.jpg) .

Rarely, eggs may become airborne and be inhaled and swallowed. Retroinfection,
or the migration of newly hatched larvae from the anal skin back into the
rectum, may occur but the frequency with which this happens is unknown.

### Hosts

Oxyurid nematodes (pinworms) generally exhibit high host specificity. Humans
are considered the only host for _E. vermicularis,_ although occasional
infections have been reported in captive chimpanzees _._

### Geographic Distribution

_E. vermicularis_ occurs worldwide, with infections occurring most frequently
in school- or preschool-children and in crowded conditions.

### Clinical Presentation

Enterobiasis is frequently asymptomatic. The most typical symptom is perianal
pruritus, especially at night, which may lead to excoriations and bacterial
superinfection. Occasionally, invasion of the female genital tract with
vulvovaginitis and pelvic or peritoneal granulomas can occur. Other symptoms
include, teeth grinding, enuresia, insomnia, anorexia, irritability, and
abdominal pain, which can mimic appendicitis. _E. vermicularis_ larvae are
often found within the appendix on appendectomy, but the role of this nematode
in appendicitis remains controversial. Very rare instances of eosinophilic
colitis associated with _E. vermicularis_ larvae have been reported.
image_gallery:
**_Enterobius vermicularis_ eggs.**

The eggs of _Enterobius vermicularis_ measure 50—60 µm by 20—30 µm. They are
transparent, elongate to oval in shape, and slightly flattened on one side.
They are usually partially embryonated when shed. Enterobiasis can be
diagnosed by applying cellulose tape to the anus of a suspect patient,
especially in the morning before the patient’s first bowel movement. Eggs will
adhere to the tape and can be seen microscopically.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Enterobius_cellulosetape.jpg?_=04216)

Figure A: Eggs of _E. vermicularis_ in a cellulose-tape preparation.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Evermicularis_egg_HBa.jpg?_=04214)

Figure B: Eggs of _E. vermicularis_ in a wet mount.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Evermicularis_egg_wtmt.jpg?_=04219)

Figure C: Egg of _E. vermicularis_ in an iodine-stained wet mount from a
formalin concentrate. Image contributed by the Kansas State Public Health
Laboratory.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Evermicularis_SC_egg.jpg?_=04221)

Figure D: Egg of _E. vermicularis_ teased from an adult worm recovered from a
colonoscopy. Image contributed by the South Carolina Department of Health and
Environmental Control, Bureau of Laboratories.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Evermicularis_egg_UVa.jpg?_=04217)

Figure E: Eggs of _E. vermicularis_ viewed under UV microscopy.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/1/Evermicularis_egg_UVb.jpg?_=04213)

Figure F: Eggs of _E. vermicularis_ viewed under UV microscopy.

**_Enterobius vermicularis_ adult worms.**

Adult males of _Enterobius vermicularis_ measure up to 2.5 mm long by 0.1-0.2
mm wide; adult females measure 8-13 mm long by 0.3-0.5 mm wide. Adult males
have a blunt posterior end with a single spicule; females possess a long
pointed tail. In both sexes, there are cephalic expansions.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Evermicularis_adult2_Norway.jpg?_=04223)

Figure A: Adult male of _E. vermicularis_ from a formalin-ethyl acetate (FEA)
concentrated stool smear. The worm measured 1.4 mm in length. Image
contributed by the Centre for Tropical Medicine and Imported Infectious
Diseases, Bergen, Norway.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Evermicularis_adult_anterior_Norway.jpg?_=04227)

Figure B: Close-up of the anterior end of the worm in Figure A. The esophagus,
divided into muscular and bulbous portions and separated by a short, narrow
isthmus, is visible in the image, as are the cephalic expansions.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Evermicularis_adult_posterior_Norway.jpg?_=04225)

Figure C: Close-up of the posterior end of the worm in Figure A. Note the
blunt end. The spicule is withdrawn into the worm in this specimen.

![Figure D](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Ent_f.jpg?_=58698)

Figure D: Adult female _E. vermicularis_ surrounded by abundant eggs.

![Figure E](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Ent_m_f.jpg?_=58700)

Figure E: Male and female _E. vermicularis_ , mounted specimens.

![Figure
F](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/2/Evermicularis_SC_posterior.jpg?_=04228)

Figure F: Posterior end of an _E. vermicularis_ female showing the long,
slender, pointed tail.

**_Enterobius vermicularis_ in tissue, stained with hematoxylin and eosin
(H&E)**

Adult males of _Enterobius vermicularis_ measure up to 2.5 mm long by 0.1—0.2
mm wide; adult females measure 8—13 mm long by 0.3-0.5 mm wide. Adult males
have a blunt posterior end with a single spicule; females possess a long
pointed tail. In both sexes, there are cephalic expansions.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/Evermicularis_worm4_HB.jpg?_=04209)

Figure A: Cross-section of a male _E. vermicularis_ from tissue, stained with
H&E. Notice the presence of the alae (blue arrow), intestine (red arrow) and
testis (black arrow).

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/Evermicularis_worm5_HB.jpg?_=04208)

Figure B: Cross-section of an adult female _E. vermicularis_ from the same
specimen shown in Figure A. Note the presence of the alae (blue arrow),
intestine (green arrow) and ovaries (black arrows).

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/Evermicularis_Sheboygan_cross.jpg?_=04211)

Figure C: Cross section of an adult female _E. vermicularis_ stained with H&E,
recovered during a colonoscopy. Note the prominent alae (blue arrow) and the
presence of eggs (yellow arrow). Image contributed by Sheboygan Memorial
Hospital, Wisconsin.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/Evermicularis_Sheboygan_longitud.jpg?_=04206)

Figure D: Longitudinal section of an adult female _E. vermicularis_ from the
same specimen as Figure C. Note the presence of many eggs.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/E_vermicularis_eggs_tissue1.jpg?_=04203)

Figure E: Egg of _E. vermicularis_ in a colon biopsy specimen, stained with
H&E.

![](/dpdx/enterobiasis/images/3/E_vermicularis_eggs_tissue2.jpg?_=04205)

Figure F: Egg of _E. vermicularis_ in a colon biopsy specimen, stained with
H&E.
lab_diagnosis:
#### Laboratory Diagnosis

Microscopic identification of eggs collected in the perianal area is the
method of choice for diagnosing enterobiasis. To improve sensitivity,
collection should be done in the morning, before defecation and washing, by
pressing transparent cellulose tape (“Scotch test”, cellulose tape slide test)
on the perianal skin and then examining the tape placed on a microscope slide.
Alternatively, anal swabs or “Swube tubes” (a paddle coated with adhesive
material) can also be used for collection. Eggs can also be found, but less
frequently, in the stool, and occasionally are encountered in the urine or
vaginal smears. Adult worms are also diagnostic, when found in the perianal
area, or during anorectal or vaginal examinations. In cases of ectopic
infection, eggs may be seen in the urine or in cervicovaginal Papanicolaou
smears.

More on: [Morphologic comparison with other intestinal
parasites.](/dpdx/diagnosticProcedures/stool/morphcomp.html)

#### Laboratory Safety

[Standard precautions](/dpdx/diagnosticprocedures/stool/safety.html) apply for
processing stool samples (also tape test samples) to avoid accidental
ingestion of infectious eggs. Surfaces should be cleaned thoroughly as the
outer coat of _E. vermicularis_ eggs is adhesive.
resources:
#### Suggested Reading

Peixoto, A., Gonçalves, R., Silva, M., Gaspar, R., Silva, R., Portugal, R. and
Macedo, G., 2016. Eosinophilic ileocolitis due to _Enterobius vermicularis_
infection: a rare cause of anemia. _International Journal of Colorectal
Disease_ , 31(3), pp.743-743.

Hasegawa, H., Takao, Y., Nakao, M., Fukuma, T., Tsuruta, O. and Ide, K., 1998.
Is _Enterobius gregorii_ Hugot, 1983 (Nematoda: Oxyuridae) a distinct species?
_The Journal of parasitology_ 84, pp.131-134.

Cook, G.C. 1994. _Enterobius vermicularis_ infection. _Gut_. 35, pp. 1159-62.
